events.originalText: A gunman involved in Islamic extremism opened fire at the Jewish Museum of Belgium in Brussels, killing four people.
events.subtitle: Islamic extremism
events.headline: Gunman opens fire at Jewish Museum of Belgium, killing four

events.originalText: An Inconvenient Truth, a documentary film that has been credited for raising international public awareness of climate change and re-energizing the environmental movement, was released.
events.subtitle: An Inconvenient Truth
events.headline: An Inconvenient Truth documentary released, raises awareness of climate change

events.originalText: The Israel Defense Forces began Operation Solomon, a covert operation to bring thousands of Ethiopian Jews to Israel (evacuees pictured).
events.subtitle: Israel Defense Forces
events.headline: Israel Defense Forces start Operation Solomon to bring Ethiopian Jews to Israel

events.originalText: Section 28 of the United Kingdom's Local Government Act of 1988, a controversial amendment stating that a local authority cannot intentionally promote homosexuality, was enacted.
events.subtitle: Section 28
events.headline: UK enacts controversial Section 28 amendment on homosexuality promotion

events.originalText: A stationary front began over the central Caribbean Sea, leading to severe floods that over two weeks killed dozens of people in Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Haiti and Jamaica.
events.subtitle: Stationary front
events.headline: Stationary front causes severe floods in Caribbean, killing dozens

events.originalText: In a wine competition in Paris, French judges shocked the wine industry by rating California wines higher than French ones.
events.subtitle: Wine competition
events.headline: French judges rate California wines higher than French in Paris competition

events.originalText: On the Kola Peninsula in Russia, drilling began on the Kola Superdeep Borehole, which eventually reached a depth of 12,262 metres (40,230 ft), making it the deepest borehole ever drilled and the lowest artificial point on Earth.
events.subtitle: Kola Peninsula
events.headline: Drilling begins on Kola Superdeep Borehole in Russia, reaches record depth

events.originalText: United States Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy met with African American author James Baldwin in an unsuccessful attempt to improve race relations.
events.subtitle: Robert F. Kennedy
events.headline: US Attorney General Kennedy meets with author Baldwin on race relations

events.originalText: Project Mercury: American astronaut Scott Carpenter orbited the Earth three times in the Aurora 7 space capsule.
events.subtitle: Project Mercury
events.headline: Astronaut Scott Carpenter orbits Earth three times in Project Mercury

events.originalText: The first edition of the Eurovision Song Contest was held in Lugano, Switzerland.
events.subtitle: Eurovision Song Contest 1956
events.headline: First Eurovision Song Contest held in Lugano, Switzerland

events.originalText: Arab–Israeli War: After five days of fighting, Egyptian forces captured the Israeli community of Yad Mordechai after the defenders had abandoned it.
events.subtitle: 1948 Arab–Israeli War
events.headline: Egyptian forces capture Israeli community after five days of fighting

events.originalText: Second World War: The German battleship Bismarck sank the British battlecruiser Hood at the Battle of the Denmark Strait.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: German battleship Bismarck sinks British battlecruiser Hood in WWII

events.originalText: English aviator Amy Johnson landed in Darwin, becoming the first woman to fly solo from England to Australia.
events.subtitle: Amy Johnson
events.headline: Amy Johnson becomes first woman to fly solo from England to Australia

events.originalText: Princess Victoria Louise of Prussia married Prince Ernest Augustus of Hanover; the occasion was one of the last great social events of European royalty before World War I began.
events.subtitle: Princess Victoria Louise of Prussia
events.headline: Princess Victoria Louise of Prussia marries Prince Ernest Augustus of Hanover

events.originalText: New York City's Brooklyn Bridge opened as the longest suspension bridge in the world at the time.
events.subtitle: Brooklyn Bridge
events.headline: Brooklyn Bridge opens as longest suspension bridge in the world

events.originalText: The nursery rhyme "Mary Had a Little Lamb" was first published as a poem by Sarah Josepha Hale.
events.subtitle: Nursery rhyme
events.headline: Nursery rhyme 'Mary Had a Little Lamb' first published as poem

events.originalText: The Irish Rebellion of 1798 began, with battles beginning in County Kildare and fighting later spreading across the country.
events.subtitle: Irish Rebellion of 1798
events.headline: Irish Rebellion of 1798 begins in County Kildare

events.originalText: At a Moravian meeting in Aldersgate, London, John Wesley (pictured) experienced a spiritual rebirth, leading him to launch the Methodist movement.
events.subtitle: Moravian Church
events.headline: John Wesley experiences spiritual rebirth at Moravian meeting in London

events.originalText: The Act of Toleration became law, granting freedom of worship to English nonconformists under certain circumstances, but deliberately excluding Catholics.
events.subtitle: Toleration Act 1688
events.headline: Act of Toleration grants freedom of worship to English nonconformists

events.originalText: Oxford University's Ashmolean Museum, the world's first university museum, opened.
events.subtitle: University of Oxford
events.headline: Ashmolean Museum at Oxford University opens as world's first university museum

events.originalText: Led by King Louis XIV, the French army invaded the Spanish Netherlands, beginning the War of Devolution.
events.subtitle: Louis XIV
events.headline: French army invades Spanish Netherlands, starting War of Devolution

events.originalText: The mentally ill King Erik XIV of Sweden and his guards murdered five incarcerated nobles, including some members of the influential Sture family.
events.subtitle: Eric XIV of Sweden
events.headline: King Erik XIV of Sweden and guards murder five nobles, including Sture family members
